Its inadequacy relates to the fact that it confers rights only on individuals and not on the community. Let us give the government credit. The government agreed with me that common law native title rights should be enforced, and that is what they are agreeing on in amendment H74. Under those circumstances, I was not prepared to press my minor improvement of the government's already inadequate statutory access scheme.

The government agreed that there should be protection of common law rights by allowing their enforcement in proceedings and preventing their exclusion, as was originally proposed in section 44C. So I am prepared to allow the statutory access to remain in place in those terms. It is better to ensure that common law rights are enforceable rather than to try to improve an inadequate statutory scheme. The proceedings for determination are already on foot in the Federal Court. It is not unreasonable to require enforcement proceedings to be brought within the existing proceedings where all the relevant material has already been filed, rather than having multiple proceedings in other courts.

So, in fact, those victims of the locked gate syndrome are able to seek access through that means. Remember, they have already made application, and it is already on foot before the Federal Court. Added to that, the government had agreed that, in respect of the registration test, the stolen generation and the victims of the locked gate syndrome should be included. I congratulate the government for that.
Progress reported.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.00 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the minister confirm that his private company, Investment Management Pty Ltd—in which he owned eight of the nine shares—purchased 2,600 Telstra shares on 25 November 1997? Can the minister confirm that these were registered to the W.R. Parer Family Trust on 27 November 1997? How does the minister reconcile this purchase of shares given the Prime Minister's explicit prohibition on the purchase of shares within 90 days of their issue? Is it the case that the minister did not understand the Prime Minister's directive; is it the case that the minister did not care about the Prime Minister's directive; or is the minister asking us to believe, yet again, that he did not receive the Prime Minister's directive?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. It sounds pretty much like a hypothetical to me. Firstly, unless Senator Faulkner has a copy of a leaked letter, he is simply asserting what the Prime Minister might or might not have said. On that basis, it falls into the category of a number of questions that have been asked by the opposition in recent times. I think it is about time that they were required to indicate whether there is a factual basis for questions before they simply put forward propositions as though they are true; in other words, a self-serving assertion which a minister is then asked to respond to. That is not the proper basis for a question. It is very misleading and ought to be ruled out of order.

—Briefly on the point of order, Madam President: we have come to expect from Senator Alston this completely dodgy point of order being taken about hypothetical questions. There were four specific questions that I asked directly to Senator Parer. You have consistently ruled Senator Alston out of order. It is just an attempt to cover up and protect his colleagues, and I would ask you to rule him out of order again.

—There were four parts to the question, and I think the first two were questions that Senator Parer may have an answer to and wish to give. As to the balance of it, I have no idea whether or not what is proposed is factual. Senator Parer may or may not know and will deal with it accordingly.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister did write to ministers in August 1997 pointing out that ministers directly involved in the Telstra sale should not buy shares in Telstra at all. Other ministers were advised not to buy shares for 90 days after the first day of trading. Spouses and children could buy shares at any time, provided they were acting independently and not merely as a proxy for the minister. Senator Ray raised this yesterday as a lead-up to this particular question and trundled around the press gallery doing what he knows best—repackaging what is already known.

answer.para: The facts are that the ownership of Telstra shares by the 28-year-old family trust was fully disclosed to the Senate in March. In fact, Senator Faulkner referred to them on 1 April this year. My wife, as I have said many times in this place, has been the manager of that trust and has been for many years. Acting independently of me, she applied for shares on the basis that I was not receiving, and had not received, any income from the trust and was not a beneficiary of the trust since I was appointed as a minister. The only people to have received benefit from the trust since that time have been my wife and the adult children.
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Just a moment, Senator Parer. Senator Alston and Senator Ray can deal with this matter at another time. You should not be shouting across the chamber while Senator Parer is answering.
—The Prime Minister's restrictions on bona fide ownership of Telstra shares did not apply to a spouse or adult family members, and the purchase was therefore in accordance with the guidelines.

answer.para: I did not apply for any shares in Telstra in accordance with the Prime Minister's letter, neither have I subsequently purchased any Telstra shares. Since 26 March, neither my wife nor I have been directors or secretary of the trust company, nor are we beneficiaries under this trust. I might say that my wife did not have to do this but elected to do so. The trust company and the trust are entirely controlled by adult children.

This is no big deal. The Labor Party would like it to be so. It is an old Labor routine. The Labor Party would be better off formulating policies than trawling around looking for mud to throw. There is not any. So my advice to Senator Faulkner is to stop wasting his time and start addressing the issues of real importance to Australia and Australians. For starters, how about having a go at formulating some policies?

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that this prohibition was imposed by the Prime Minister in order to reassure everyone that no minister would benefit from a crucial government decision? I might ask also whether making a few thousand dollars is more important to the minister than the need to comply with the Prime Minister's ministerial standards.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —That is correct. And I might say that personally I have not benefited in any way whatsoever from the purchase of those shares.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I put it to the minister that all political parties have a responsibility to provide detailed, costed policies prior to the next election. Will the minister outline the government's economic policies in achieving record low interest rates, record low inflation and a massive reduction in Labor's debt? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies to continue the government's responsible management of the Australian economy?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —Yes, the contrast is dramatic between the sound economic management of the Howard government and the appalling economic mess that we inherited when we came to government. Just look at interest rates that are so important to all Australians.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think a couple of journalists might just have been asked to leave the gallery because they were not wearing jackets. Is there a rule for male journalists that does not apply to female journalists; and, if so, would you look at it please?
—Yes.

—It won't interest Senator Brown, but we are talking about the economic welfare of the country and all Australians. We are comparing interest rates under Labor with that of the coalition government. Under Labor, home interest rates got to 17 per cent compared with 6.7 per cent for the coalition. Under Labor, small business interest rates were 20 per cent compared with about seven per cent for the Howard government. As to debt, we had a budget deficit of $10.3 billion under Labor compared with a surplus of $2.7 billion under the coalition. Under Labor, Commonwealth debt totalled around $100 billion, with an additional $70 billion of debt in its last five years of government, compared with the coalition government actually repaying debt. The debt to GDP ratio will be 7.5 per cent in the year 2000 compared with Labor's 20 per cent. Turning to jobs, you will remember unemployed rising to one million in this country under Labor; under the coalition that figure is down to 8.1 per cent.

answer.para: That is the record to be compared. But the voters will also be asking, `What of the future?' They will be asking of Labor—particularly against the background of its appalling record—`What of the future?' Of course, they had the right, and still have the right, to expect clear policies from the Labor Party. Last year, Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition said:
The next phase of Labor's journey back into government is deliberation on detailed, properly costed election promises.

talk.start.para: —Yes.
—A reasonable statement, Senator Cook; you agree with it. But by this year, he was starting to wriggle out of that commitment. His next statement was:

answer.para: We are going to have to, I think, in this election campaign give an indication of our intentions as opposed to necessarily a final statement.
So clear policies have been reduced to an indication. But most recently he has gone a step further. In June of this year, Mr Beazley said:
. . . but what I am going to do when I actually get into power is put forward a set of policies which I believe the Australian people will rally to . . .

Last year he said that he had policies, that he was going to put down clear and detailed policies. Then he said he was going to put down a framework for policies. Now he says that when he gets into government he will show the Australian people his policies.

Last year, Mr Evans, who is the shadow Treasurer—although some might fail to understand that—said, `We have actually been up to our armpits in policy formulation.' They were up to their armpits in policy formulation last year, but now Mr Beazley says, `You are not going to get it until after the election.' Why? One wonders if we got a hint last weekend from shadow Treasurer Evans when he talked about the wholesale sales tax. He said, `Well, some might go up and some might come down.' But we know that with the Labor Party taxes always go up. After the 1993 election, whatever they promised, taxes went up. After 1995, taxes went up again. What will the people understand from the failure of Mr Beazley to come clean on policy? They will expect the worst, and they will have every right to, because that has been the history, the legacy, of Labor after 13 years in government: high interest rates, high taxation and high debt. If they get back into office, the Australian people will get it again.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of any advice regarding the importance of outlining in detail various policies? Does the government agree with that advice?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I am aware of some advice. Senator Cook will remember advice that was received by an interested commentator in February 1995. That commentator said:

answer.para: Tell us how you are going to pay for all these promises . . . Tell us what you are going to do by way of outlays. Tell us what you are going to do by way of tax revenue increases.

. . .. if the opposition thinks it is going to get away with having it both ways forever—making all these promises and not explaining to the electorate how they are going to be paid, whether by way of other outlay reductions or by way of tax increases—it has got another think coming.

That was Gareth Evans in 1995. If it was good enough for the Liberal Party to come clean on policies, it is now good enough for the Labor Party to do the same. It is time the Labor Party came clean on policies. Tell us what your tax policy is, and the people will have better options at the next election.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the minister now confirm that other companies closely associated with him bought Telstra shares during the initial public offer? Specifically, will the minister acknowledge that the following purchases by his family companies breach the intent of the Prime Minister's prohibition: Gashbah Pty Ltd, 3,000 Telstra shares; Spanlex Pty Ltd for the Rutherglen Superannuation Fund, 5,000 Telstra shares; and Spanlex Pty Ltd for the Warwick R. Parer No. 2 Account, 2,200 Telstra shares? Can the minister now confirm that at the time of the Telstra float, he and his spouse, through various entities, purchased 15,000 Telstra shares, not including the further 12,800 shares purchased in the names of his immediate family?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I think I explained earlier that all my family affairs have in fact been managed by my wife, going back many years. She made an independent decision that there was no beneficial interest accruing to me because I received no income and have not been a nominated beneficiary since I have been a minister.

answer.para: This is really an intrusion, I would have to say, Senator. When you talk about Rutherglen, that is the private superannuation company that my wife has had for quite a long time. If you are going to go into the depths—and it would be, I know, low for the Labor Party—to go down the track of attacking the independence of wives of senators and members, you have reached a new low.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that he is a public office holder and it is vital that his personal interests not be entangled with his public duties. Can the minister confirm that the Telstra Corporation share register held by Coopers and Lybrand shows that at least 24 parcels of Telstra shares were purchased by members of his immediate family or by companies or entities closely associated with him?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —They could have been; I wouldn't know. I have seven adult children and what their affairs are is entirely up to them. It is the same for my wife or anyone else's wife.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Will the minister outline the achievements of the coalition government in the area of social security? Is the minister aware of the alternative policies and implications if they were to be implemented?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McGauran for the question. After two years and four months we have made enormous strides in reforms in the social security system, and all Australians, I know, will be glad. When you think of the family tax initiative, which was a massive expenditure in the first year to help battling families; when you think of the youth allowance, which treats students more fairly than they ever have been in the past; when you think of the measures for retirees, for pensioners, for carers and for the disabled—in every area of social security policy, this government has produced important reforms.

answer.para: The profoundly disabled children's measure was contested by the other parties in the Senate until they saw reason. The jobs and education and training program has been extended to partnered parents as well as to lone parents; the increase in pensions to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings has been enshrined in legislation—never before done; there is retirement assistance for farmers on non-viable farms. I could go on and on. We did a lot; we have done a lot.

But what is the situation with the opposition? All we have seen from the Labor Party is an indication of a wish list of policies that we can only glean from the amendments that they try to pass in this place, because they are bereft of a policy on this area. They bring out wishy-washy statements—it would appear they are promises—by people who are in a position to make promises, such as Cheryl Kernot, Jenny Macklin and Gareth Evans, and any other Labor spokesperson. They are not policies; they are promises on the run to the audience that suits them at the time.

Of course, the bulk of Labor's contribution to social policy debate is scare campaigns. We have seen it constantly in the last few days about the youth allowance. Yesterday, we had Senator Carr in here giving us what he purports to be factual information—once again not factual information, Senator Carr. The family concerned are getting an allowance—

talk.start.para: —Senator, your answers should be directed to the chair, not directly to the senator.

—I am sorry, Madam President. Yesterday in the Senate, Senator Carr misrepresented the situation for a young person, which is why you would take with scepticism any claims made by a Labor spokesman. That is why the public should not take notice of them.

answer.para: Just think of the proposed amendments that Labor made to the 1997 social security budget and other measures bill—$36 million extra per annum. Then it wants a $40 million amendment to the payments processing bill. In 1996 and 1997 the opposition parties opposed a host of measures, which would have cost hundreds of millions of dollars over a four-year period.

They have no policy, but they try to put things in that they do not have to pay for because they will never be in government. There is the `Cheryl Kernot clause' for the baby-boomers; winding back the superannuation as part of the income test—a fair measure that treats all savings the same, but it is a measure that the Labor Party introduced that subsidises the superannuation-rich at the expense of everybody else. Cheryl Kernot wants to put it back.

They are just a taste of the things about which Labor is making promises on the run—not policy on the run, because we have not seen a sign of it yet. These proposals of Labor are simply designed to focus on any particular interest group they are speaking to at the time. When are we going to see it in writing? When are we going to see properly costed policies?

The biggest thing of all, of course, as Senator Patterson would well know, is the Labor proposal to increase all allowances to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. What is the cost to the taxpayer of that one? That is only $4.35 billion over four years—and I said billion, not million. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the minister advise why in his letter to the Prime Minister, tabled in this place on 23 March, he indicated that his spouse did own 2,200 Telstra shares, but he failed to mention that IMPL, of which he was chairman and controlled eight of the nine shares at the time, had purchased 2,600 Telstra shares? Why didn't he declare that? In his declaration to the Prime Minister, which he was required to make, did the minister indicate to the Prime Minister the Telstra shareholdings in IMPL, Gashbah Pty Ltd, the Rutherglen Superannuation Fund, and the Warwick R. Parer Family Trust No. 2 account? If the minister did this, did he get a letter back from the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet indicating that those affairs were in order and in compliance with the Prime Minister's directive on these matters?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —Senator Ray will be perfectly aware that I made full disclosure to the Senate in March this year of all holdings. He would also know that when one makes a declaration to the Prime Minister it includes a lot more detail than is required in the Senate declarations. All I can say is that full disclosure was made to the Prime Minister in accordance with his requirements.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Are you saying, Minister, that you in fact declared to the Prime Minister those four particular parcels that I mentioned in full detail? We do not require the detail obviously, but did you actually do that? Did you get a letter back from Mr Max Moore-Wilton saying that it was all right? By the way, Minister, when you declared these matters—you said fully—to the Senate, did you just declare the IMPL holding, or did you declare the holdings in Spanlex, Gashbah and the other accounts?
—I point out to Senator Ray that you directed all of that directly across to the minister, and I think you are perfectly aware that you ought not to do it in that fashion.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Ray knows better than anyone else that no-one is required to disclose the detail of what is contained in private correspondence to the Prime Minister, and yet here he is—his top gear, unctuous self—saying, `All I really want is for you to confirm certain matters,' and then he spells them out in detail. In other words, he is asking Senator Parer to identify precisely what he told the Prime Minister, and Senator Parer is not required to do that. Senator Ray knows it; he is simply trying to pretend that somehow he is not wanting the detail. All that Senator Parer needs to be asked in this chamber is whether he has complied with the existing requirements. He has already said that he has, and there is absolutely no basis at all for Senator Ray seeking further and better particulars—trawling and fishing in the bottom of the gutter—trying to somehow distract attention from Labor's total and absolute failure to address policy issues.
—There is no point of order. Senator Parer is able to answer the question and will do so.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I made full disclosure to the Senate, as did my wife in a private disclosure that is required. I might also point out that to verify that, I got the accountants who have been looking after our affairs for many a long year to put a piece of paper together because I was concerned about making sure that there was full disclosure.
—You didn't table that in your letter to the Senate, did you?
—Yes, it is there.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I am wondering if the minister is aware of a television advertisement in the government's $3.8 million promotional campaign for the common youth allowance which suggests that a young woman living away from home with members of her extended family will be eligible for living away from home allowance and rent assistance. Isn't it the case, though, according to the DSS guidelines, that such allowance is only available in very limited circumstances—for students in the most remote areas where no school is located or for students with disabilities requiring special facilities? Isn't it true that it is not available when a student chooses to remain at their current school, so as not to disturb his or her studies, as depicted in the advertisement? Rather than giving the information that young people really need as opposed to what Senator Tambling described as their rights and responsibilities in the new system, isn't it the government that is perpetuating these fallacies about the common youth allowance?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I would like to answer Senator Stott Despoja by asking her when is she going to acknowledge how important this is for students; when is she going to acknowledge what a massive increase this will mean for students, whether they are from country districts, from regional Australia or whether they are city kids. The grudging and carping criticism that comes from an ideological position that we have been hearing from opposition parties—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order as to relevance. This was a specific question on truth in advertising and I ask the minister to answer the question, please.
—I would draw the minister's attention to the question but she has nearly 3½ minutes left to deal with it.

—I have plenty more to say, Senator Lees. As you would realise, Madam President, this is an enormous new policy. It has huge ramifications in that it has put two policy areas together, it has put five payments into one and it has reduced the 13 rates of payment. But in doing that—
—How do they get living away from home allowance? Answer the question.
—Madam President, we are still getting shouting from the fairies at the bottom of the garden.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Stott Despoja asked a question of the minister, and even if Senator Stott Despoja is not interested in the answer, I am. I would ask you to require Senator Stott Despoja to desist from continually interjecting.
—If she is interjecting, I didn't hear it because of other interjections much nearer to me. It would be better if all senators abide by the standing orders, and then everyone could hear the answer.

—Senator Stott Despoja and her friends in the National Union of Students have consistently refused to recognise what a major social policy reform this is and of what enormous benefit it is to students. Having said that, it is a huge undertaking which has brought these two payments together and aligned the entitlements for two quite disparate payments. It means that young people, whether they are students or unemployed, are treated the same. There is not better treatment of the unemployed than the students. It brings the students up to the unemployed level.

answer.para: Inevitably, even if we had spent $50 million on advertising, you could not have covered all the intricacies of recognising the needs of young people in their different circumstances. If Senator Stott Despoja would like the government to spend more money on advertising the youth allowance in even greater detail, I would be very happy to consider it because I think it is something which needs to go out to all of Australia. I am proud of this measure and I would hope that students get the correct information and are not party to a scare campaign from the opposition—I mentioned earlier Senator Carr's efforts yesterday, and we have had other examples on the media.

If young people and their families have an opportunity to get the facts, they will know how beneficial this is. I would be very happy to have Senator Stott Despoja endorse increased expenditure because it is such a big measure, and it does need to cover every eventuality that young people face, whether they are sick, whether they are studying, whether they are part-time job searching and part-time studying or whether they are in training. There are lots of exemptions for young people in certain circumstances. It depends on their age and whether they live away from home—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order as to relevance. I asked a specific question about whether a particular student would be entitled to the living away from home allowance and rent assistance. This is not a hypothetical; it is according to the government's own advertising campaign. I have waited for a number of minutes and have given the minister an opportunity to answer the question. She has not even mentioned living away from home allowance in the context of answering the question.
—I cannot direct the minister as to how she answers, but she is certainly dealing with the topic that was raised by the senator in her question.

—The fact is, as Senator Stott Despoja well knows, that there are lots of circumstances in social security payments where the Centrelink officers are required under legislation to exercise discretion, and they operate under guidelines set down by the Secretary of the Department of Social Security. She is referring now to an area where there is a requirement for discretion in the implementation of those guidelines.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Despite the noise and the bellowing from Senator Carr—who cannot tell the truth in the Senate—that is the answer that Senator Stott Despoja needs to have. If she wants more information, we would be very happy to brief her. I have offered her that sort of briefing before but I have not noticed that she is so keen to get into the fine print and look at all the detail.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, not that much came out of that question. First of all, does the minister acknowledge that my office has taken advantage of briefings? Does the minister stand by this advertisement as `fulfilling the DSS guidelines'? Does the minister accept that truth in advertising is important? Does she stand by the information, the so-called fact, contained in the common youth allowance advertisement which implies that students in the situation outlined by the father who was talking about his daughter would be entitled to living away from home allowance and rent assistance? Does the minister stand by her advertisement?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —Perhaps Senator Stott Despoja does not understand the way these advertising campaigns are developed. They are certainly not developed by the minister.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—The quickest way to answer Senator Stott Despoja is to say that this advertising was developed by and for Centrelink, which is the organisation entrusted under the legislation to administer the legislation. I would therefore be totally reliant upon their accurate reflection in the advertising.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Does the minister recall including in his declaration of pecuniary interests his holding of shares in the diversified investment company Argo Investments Ltd? Is the minister aware that the 1997 annual report for Argo Investments Ltd indicates at page 4 that one of the largest investments made by Argo is in BHP, with $24.1 million worth of shares? Is the minister further aware that Argo Investments also has substantial holdings in the resources companies Ashton Mining, CSR, Renison Gold, North Ltd, Rio Tinto, Santos and Western Mining? Given that the minister felt it necessary to sell his own CSR shares in October last year because that company held an interest in the mining company Nabalco, why has he not felt it necessary to divest his Argo Investments shares for the very same reason?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —Senator Evans is quite right. On my being appointed we got rid of, or my wife got rid of, all shares in regard to direct involvement in the mining industry. Advice was sought at the time, and it was pointed out that this is basically an investment company which is equivalent to what you would almost call a blind trust. You have no control over it whatsoever, no interest in it whatsoever. You can have no influence on it whatsoever in any shape or form. For that reason, it was agreed that that sort of investment was satisfactory in accordance with the guidelines.

answer.para: I might also say that at the time advice was sought, similar advice was received in respect of a company called Australia Foundation, which has a broad portfolio of shares over which there is no interest. I do not know personally what particular investments those companies have. It is a blind investment. It is up to them as to how they make those investments.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, but are you aware that the 1997 annual report of Argo Investments lists at page 31 some 143,000 shares in the company Energy Resources of Australia Ltd? Can the minister assure the Senate that he has at no time since becoming minister made any decision relating to Energy Resources of Australia? I remind the minister that the ERA is the operator of the Jabiluka uranium mine. If the minister cannot give such an assurance, and given the precedent set by Senator Gibson, what action does he now propose to take?
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order.
—You got rid of your shares in a big hurry in April.
—What have you done with your money?

—I think we would like to know what you have done with all your investments after 10 years as a minister, too. There is not much to show for it, is there? Madam President, the only possible relevance of that question asked by Senator Evans is whether or not Senator Parer had any capacity to control or influence the decision making process of that company. What he has conceded is that at one point in the year—in other words, an annual report snapshot—it might be possible to determine what shares were owned by an investment company. That report itself comes out long after the period to which it refers. There can be no possible basis for suggesting that Senator Parer would be aware of the holdings of that company at any one point in time relevant to the decision making process. There is no possible basis for suggesting that he could affect any decision made. It is therefore utterly irrelevant.
—There is no point of order.

—Madam President, I rise on a further point of order, which is a point of order. Senator Alston is deliberately using the tactic of taking non-points of order through the device of points of order during question time to attempt to give Senator Parer some cover on questions properly directed to him. The issues relating to the standing orders or procedural or process issues before the Senate are not even discussed or canvassed at all in any of these phoney points of order that Senator Alston is taking as a device to cover up for Senator Parer. I ask you, Madam President, if he does it again to discipline him.
—There is no point of order.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —The groups to which Senator Evans referred have a portfolio of stocks. If he wants to go down that track it would mean that no-one in this place can have an investment in a superannuation company or in any financial institution, because people like AMP, people like—
—Why did you sell CSR?
—Because they were a direct investment, Senator. That is why. Can't you understand? You are as thick as a brick.
—What about ERA?
—Senator Faulkner, one of your senators has asked a question, and he should be able to hear the answer.

—It means that no-one here can have a superannuation fund or an insurance policy with a company, whether it be AMP, National Mutual or any other organisation or financial institution of that type, because they do have broad portfolios of investments, the same as this particular group. As I mentioned earlier, this was the sort of advice that I sought, in fact I got my wife to seek, before she agreed to make those investments.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Given the substantial amount of work being carried out by the World Trade Organisation's Committee on Trade and Environment in reviewing the relationship of multilateral environment agreements to the World Trade Organisation and its annexed agreements, can the minister advise the Senate: to what extent is the minister and/or his department involved in attending meetings of the Committee on Trade and Environment; what meetings has he or representatives of his department attended? What level of advice does the minister and/or his department give to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade prior to meetings of the Committee on Trade and Environment; and what level of consultation does he or his department have with environment groups and other relevant stakeholders prior to the meetings of the Committee on Trade and Environment?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I have not attended those meetings. They are attended by the Minister for Trade or his representative. We are aware of the issues, and we do provide advice through the internal systems of government. But it has not gone beyond that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the paucity of the minister's response, what action does the minister intend taking to rectify this low level of participation by him, his department and other major stakeholders at meetings of the Committee on Trade and Environment? Has the minister or his department approached the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to have environment groups and other relevant stakeholders attend meetings of the Committee on Trade and Environment as part of the Australian government delegation as observers—as potentially he would do, I guess, for industry stakeholders?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —This is principally a trade negotiation. Certainly, through this committee, it does look at some issues where environmental consequences might have some effect upon trade determinations. What we do is seek to ensure that the environmental consequences are properly understood by those who are negotiating on behalf of Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the minister confirm the transfer of 2,600 Telstra shares from IMPL to the recently established company White Rhinos Pty Ltd on 25 June 1998? Can the minister confirm that the shares held by Investment Management Pty Ltd in Campbells, Woolworths, Simsmetal, Argo Investments, Australian Provincial Newspapers, Bank of Queensland and Buderim Ginger were also transferred to White Rhinos Pty Ltd; and, if not, where were they transferred to? Can the minister outline what, if anything, in the articles of association of White Rhinos prevents the beneficial ownership of any or all of these shareholdings reverting to him immediately on his ceasing to hold ministerial office?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —The shares did not transfer; they still remain in the family trust. What did change was the management company. The other day Senator Cook questioned in here whether, in fact, Investment Management still exists. I pointed out to him that it was shell company which was in the process of being deregistered.

answer.para: Where it sits at the moment, neither my wife nor I are directors of White Rhinos Pty Ltd, which is the new—that is, in fact, now controlled by adult children. Neither are we beneficiaries under the trust, and neither can we be beneficiaries under the trust.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the minister's answer to my question, I ask the minister: how does the transfer of assets to White Rhinos Pty Ltd comply with the Prime Minister's guide to the key elements of ministerial responsibility, which states that `the transfer of interests to a family member, or to a nominee or trust, is not an acceptable form of divestment'?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —Senator Faulkner really is a bit slow, because my recollection is that the Prime Minister himself answered that question by stating that that did not refer to adult children who are totally independent.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. All political parties have a public responsibility to provide detailed policies prior to the next federal election. What steps has the coalition government taken to clearly enunciate its policies in the vital area of communications? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches; and, if he is, do they commend themselves to the government? If not, why not?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Yes, I think Senator Gibson is absolutely right—that the Australian public would expect nothing less and they will be looking, no doubt, very carefully to see what is on offer in the lead-up to the next election. But I have to say that they must be bitterly disappointed today to see yet again the time of this chamber occupied with gutter crawling of the most sleaziest kind with the opposition simply neglecting, once again, opportunities to put forward any positive policy alternatives.

answer.para: We are about to debate the Telstra bill—I do not want to go into the details of that— and, quite clearly, that spells out very specifically a number of policy initiatives that we are taking, how the structure of that sale would occur, and what safeguards are built into the process. Of course, over the last couple of years we have introduced a number of historic new initiatives—customer service guarantees, the ISDN initiatives. There is plenty for consumers in our approach to these issues.

But what do we have from Labor to date? Go back to the Hobart document. About the only thing in it of any substance was the commitment to the unions that `Labor opposes the sale of Telstra and will not sell any further portion'. We know how expendable that is because Senator Schacht has been out there recently saying that they would only keep it in majority control.

But, if you look at the rest of that document, Madam President, it is full of blitheringly trite statements, like `Labor supports the right of all Australians to have equitable access to a modern telecommunications system' and `Labor supports a national telecommunications system which avoids, wherever possible, unnecessary duplication' and `Labor supports a competitive regime'. Of course they do. You introduced it, you got the NCC off the ground, so it is your initiative. There is nothing else in that document that could remotely be described as a policy alternative.

What I think the Australian public want to know is: why isn't the Labor Party interested in, at the very least, giving guarantees to retain customer service guarantees, price caps and untimed local calls? Why can't you even bring yourself to commit to those sorts of initiatives?

What about the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund? Are you going to wind that up halfway through? You have said nothing about it to date. What about the mess that you created in the phase-out of the analog mobile telephone network? Are you going to do anything about it? Why will you not even refer to it in your document? The pastoral call rebate, which we introduced: are you going to retain that? There is not a word of it in this document.

There are so many things in our policy which are good for consumers. There is absolutely nothing in this document apart from a blank cheque, apart from a highly expendable commitment to the trade union movement. As for the rest of it, it is, `Once we get into government, we will tell you what we are going to do.' We remember 1993. We remember the l-a-w, law tax cuts. We remember what happened. You welched on the biggest commitment in history. What did you do instead? You introduced additional increases to the wholesale sales tax of almost $14 billion. It was the greatest treachery in political history.

There is one thing that ought to be abundantly clear: it is about time the Labor Party came clean. They cannot be believed on a number of these issues, certainly on tax reform. Why will they not at the very least put out a document that at least maintains the status quo? I know Senator Schacht spent most of Christmas reading the One Minute Manager. He thought he could apply that to telecommunications policy, so he came up with a five-minute document. But, even if you have not got any policy thoughts or any new initiatives in your mind, why can't you at least lock into the status quo? Why can't you assure people that they will not get timed local calls? Why can't you assure them they will get customer protections? Why can't you think of consumers at all, because you have not to date? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Will the minister now come clean to the Senate and confirm that his 16 C-class shares—
—Order! Senator Parer is entitled to hear the question.

—Will the minister now come clean to the Senate and confirm that his 16 C-class shares in QCMM were transferred to White Rhinos Pty Ltd? If this is not the case, to whom were they transferred and when? Or has the minister taken no action on this blatant conflict of interest with his ministerial responsibilities, despite numerous undertakings to do so?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I know Senator Cook runs off talking to accountants around town because he does not understand business. I think he showed that very clearly when he was a minister in government, when you look at the disasters that occurred over 13 years. Who can forget the famous R&D syndication program?

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The behaviour in the chamber is totally unacceptable and in breach of the standing orders. I would ask senators to observe them.

—If Senator Cook had listened to the last question I answered on this issue, he would know that the family trust, which has been in existence for 28 years, remains intact. The only thing that happened is that Investment Management Pty Ltd, which was the manager of the trust, was actually removed as manager of the trust and the new trustee company was formed, of which, as I pointed out earlier, neither my wife nor I have any interests either as a director—
—Why don't you call it white elephant, rather than white rhino, Warwick?

—That is a good question. I will answer that after question time if you like. As I mentioned in around March last year, what it did was legally put into effect what in fact had been happening for many years in respect of the beneficiaries of the trust; being—as was the intent right back in 1970—for the benefit of the children.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that it has been revealed that White Rhinos Pty Ltd is the minister's pseudo-divestment vehicle, does the minister still claim that he complied with the ministerial code of conduct by transferring his coal shares to that family company? Does the minister deny that he remains in a position to regain control of those coal company assets within minutes of ceasing to be a minister?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Under standing orders, a supplementary question has to relate to the answer that has been given. Quite clearly, the question is not a supplementary because Senator Cook began his question with `now it has been revealed'. Senator Parer revealed nothing of the sort. It must be ruled out of order because it cannot be a supplementary to the original question.
—It is a very tenuous connection. If Senator Parer has anything he wants to say, he may do so.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I will help to educate Senator Cook. All assets which are part of the family trust, as I said going back many years, including real estate, are now under the control of White Rhinos. As regards to `whether you can take control', the answer to that is really no. It is under the control of seven adult children. What they do down the track is entirely up to them. But I remind Senator Cook that, when you think of the reason trusts are set up in the first place, it is probably worth quoting Keynes: in the long run we'll all be dead.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Can the minister say how many Federal Police investigations have been conducted into alleged leaks in the environment department since your government came to office? How many public servants have been interviewed, subjected to disciplinary action or charged as a result of these investigations? How many Federal Police investigations were there into the environment department in the three years prior to this government coming to office? A spokesperson for Senator Hill told the West Australian that the Federal Police investigations into leaks from government departments was `standard operating practice'. Can the minister advise when this became standard practice and at whose direction? As leaks are commonplace, how many other departments are being investigated at present? What is the cost, and how does this compare with the same period under Labor? I point out that I have given the minister plenty of notice of this question, and I would appreciate a full reply.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for her question. Madam President, if you are happy to let her have a question with notice during questions without notice, I am happy to go along with it as best I can. As I am advised, 50 leaks of information have been referred for investigation to the Federal Police during the period March 1996 to date, and of those seven have been referred by the former Department of Environment, Sport and Territories or its successor Environment Australia.

answer.para: There is a longstanding procedure in place, as I am advised, adopted by the Fraser government and continued by successive governments since then for the referral of such matters to the Australian Federal Police. The procedure requires that matters of a politically sensitive nature requiring the assistance of the Federal Police should be raised with the minister responsible for the Federal Police in the first instance rather than being directly referred to the Federal Police. That procedure ensures that the government is informed at the earliest juncture of potentially politically contentious matters that might require Federal Police investigation. An exemption from that policy is made in the case of Australian Electoral Commission matters.

The Federal Police conducts each investigation into all matters referred under this process thoroughly and independently without political interference. It does not receive orders from ministers or departmental heads on what it investigates or how it undertakes its investigations. It would not be appropriate to comment in any detail on any investigations under way. There are sound and proper operational and privacy considerations which make this approach essential.

The AFP, as you might expect, would not—and, as I am advised, does not—have a record of any disciplinary action that may be initiated by any department. That is a matter for the particular departments to pursue if public servants are not following the requirements of their employ. I can advise that the AFP maintains a special investigations team for such investigations. The resources allocated for each individual investigation depend on the priority and obviously the complexity of the matter.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has partially answered my questions, but if I can ask again: isn't it the case that there are more police investigations into Environment Australia than other departments? How does the minister explain that? Isn't it also the case that there are leaks from government sources on a regular basis? Given that this is a standard procedure, can the minister provide a breakdown by department of Federal Police investigations showing the number of people interviewed, those subjected to disciplinary procedures, those charged and the resources used in each of those investigations?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I will take that question on notice. Senator, if you were interested in the proper use of resources, you might not have asked that question. The Federal Police have got a quite bit to do other than chase around and give reports to the Senate on minor investigations they have done and how many hours it has taken. I can see some poor soul being given this task and going down to the bowels of the Federal Police filing system, never to be seen again. I understand the generality of what you are after, Senator, and if we can discuss this after question time and come to some reasonable understanding of what you want to know at no great cost, we will be happy to comply as best we can.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the minister confirm that the metamorphosis from IMPL to White Rhinos basically occurred on 25 June 1998? Can he confirm that, as part of those arrangements, White Rhinos took over the management of 2,600 Telstra shares worth $11,310; 46,937 Australian Foundation Investment shares worth $124,383; 12,037 Argo Investments shares worth $38,518; 11,223 Woolworths shares worth $58,920; and 2,918 Simsmetal shares worth $20,426?

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. How can it possibly be relevant to be asking the Minister for Resources and Energy whether he had Woolworths shares? This is just an excuse and an opportunity for Senator Ray to play the politics of greed and envy and to trot out a whole list of investments by a particular company.
—Senator Alston, which standing order are you referring to? Keep it brief.
—Relevance, Madam President, purely and simply. What possible relevance has Woolworths got to do with Senator Parer's ministerial responsibility?
—There is no point of order.

—Minister, were those shares transferred to White Rhinos? Were they at that value? Minister, when is enough enough? Surely that was enough for you and the rest of them. Why did you have to crowd out all of the battlers in the Telstra float? (Time expired)

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. There is no way at all that the issue of the value they were transferred at can be relevant to this minister's portfolio. The other point on relevance is that, as Senator Parer has said, he has maintained no beneficial interest in share portfolios since he has been a minister.

—No, it is important—he has had no beneficial interest while he has been a minister. There were ongoing complaints about the structure of a trustee company and what he then did was transfer interests away from it. So we are not talking here about transferring to Senator Parer; we are talking about transferring away. Yet we have spent a whole question time talking about that. There is no way that that can be relevant to the administration by Senator Parer of his portfolio responsibilities and it should be, therefore, ruled out of order.

—On the point of order, Madam President: we have already had clear evidence presented in question time today that Argo Investments have considerable holdings in ERA. A decision has been made by this Minister for Resources and Energy relating to Energy Resources of Australia, a very well-known decision—in fact, the go-ahead for the Jabiluka uranium mine. I suggest to you, Madam President, that all of the question Senator Ray has asked is in order. I think you have established a clear precedent in question time that that is the case. Senator Alston and Senator Hill are covering up for Senator Parer.
—Senator Faulkner, you ought not to be making that allegation. There is a valid point of order which you are entitled to make. You should not go on and make those sorts of assertions.

—Madam President, I make this procedural point to you: I believe both Senator Alston and Senator Hill are using the device of a point of order to ensure that this minister catches his breath and gets an opportunity to think how on earth he can get out of the jam he is in.

—On a point of order, Madam President: I want to go not to the three points made so far, but to the relevance of my question. Senator Parer came into this chamber some months ago and asked for leave to table documents which indicated a course of action. I thought he did so as a minister. I asked in my question whether the transfer occurred on 25 June—in bulk, not in its entirety. I have referred to the five company shares that are discoverable on the register so far. We can get the rest from Queensland tomorrow. I asked whether they occurred on that date and about the amount of those shares so that I could scrutinise whether Senator Parer has kept his commitments made in this chamber in writing. I thought the question was in order. If Senator Parer does not want to go to some elements of it, it will not surprise anyone.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I am happy to answer that question. The transfers occurred towards the end of March. This was done with leading lawyers and accountants around town. With regard to the actual transfers, the date on which both my wife and I moved away from any sort of responsibility in regard to the board or the management of the trust was on about 26 March.

answer.para: Senator Cook raised a question the other day as to whether the Investment Management company had been deregistered. One of the things I found out, Senator Cook—because I was not too sure; I know the instructions were given—was that these things take time. One of the things you must do, apparently, is advertise in case there are some liabilities against it. I gather that that process is going on. Irrespective of that, with regard to the transfers across to White Rhinos as the manager, to my knowledge, and in accordance with the instructions given to me by people who should know more than me, including the solicitors and accountants, it all occurred at about the end of March.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, in the process of this transfer, did it ever occur to you that your holding in Australian Foundation Investments involved you in further interests in companies such as CSR, Plutonic Resources, QCT Resources, Rio Tinto, Santos, Western Mining, Woodside Petroleum and, indeed, $59 million worth of BHP shares?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I thought I answered that question earlier. One of the difficulties related to deciding what companies should be invested in. The advice that was received from the brokers at the time was that these were arms-length type investments—as I said earlier, very similar to National Mutual and AMP. If you go down that track, it means that nobody in this place can have any superannuation or any insurance policy, because that is what these companies do.
—What is wrong with parliamentary super?

—Nothing, Senator. Madam President, if you look at the percentages of the total, and bearing in mind that they are large investment companies, it is a very tiny amount and it would be similar to the sort of thing that one would invest in a super fund or an insurance policy.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—During question time, Madam President, I drew your attention to the fact that some people were asked to leave the press gallery. I have looked at the standing orders. I note that standing order 175 says that people will be asked to leave if there is a disturbance, but there has been no disturbance. I ask: if it is the case that there are dress rules which apply to men but not to women which are being invoked in this situation—it has happened twice in the last week—will you ensure that they are applied across the board and that the basic tenet of being well dressed is enough to allow somebody to be present in the gallery and not removed from covering the proceedings of the Senate?

—You raised this matter earlier during question time. I have not had an opportunity to find out anything about what has happened today or at any other time. It is the first I have heard of it. I will make the inquiries that I indicated I would do.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, Senator Ray asked me a series of questions about prime ministerial notices to his ministers and their staff in relation to buying Telstra shares. The Prime Minister wrote to ministers in August 1997 pointing out that ministers and staff directly involved in the Telstra sale, who might therefore be privy to privileged information, should not buy shares in Telstra. Other ministers and parliamentary secretaries and their staff were advised not to buy shares for 90 days after the first trade. Spouses and children could buy shares at any time, provided they were acting independently and not merely as proxies.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —by leave—Last Thursday, the Senate ordered that the government produce electorate issues briefs prepared by departments at the request of ministers or their offices. I am told that departments have supplied electorate briefs to their ministers on request from ministers or their offices for many years. I am informed that such a brief probably would obtain geographical, electoral, economic and industrial data relating to the electorate. This is the sort of material available from the Australian Electoral Commission and the Parliamentary Handbook . It would also contain a summary of the portfolio's activities in the electorate and a summary of current issues relevant to the portfolio. Briefs provided to the Prime Minister are comprehensive and summarise all portfolios' activities in the electorate.

speech.para: I am also told that the practice of supplying electorate briefs varies widely between departments. Some departments supply them; some do not. Some ministers request them; some do not. I cannot personally remember requesting such a brief. Madam President, I am endeavouring to discover how widespread is the use of the briefs across this government, and I have asked for some examples to satisfy myself as to their scope and content. I am awaiting that information—so what I am giving you is an interim report—and I expect to receive that soon. When I have had an opportunity to evaluate the information, I will report again.

I note that in 1995, Senator Abetz suggested to an estimates hearing that the electorate briefs provided to the then Prime Minister might be tabled. Former Senator McMullan indicated that the nature of the documents had not changed, at least in the case of the Prime Minister, for a long time, perhaps decades, and pointed out that they had never before been tabled. In a written reply, the government indicated the type of information provided in the briefs, but no more. I presume that the type of information provided in the briefs is what Senator Faulkner was really seeking from this resolution.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the financial interests of Senator Parer

Senator Parer is guilty of three offences. He has openly defied the code of ministerial conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) by divesting shares to family members, he has defied the Prime Minister's instructions to his ministers in relation to the purchase of Telstra shares within 90 days of the Telstra float, and he has deliberately concealed the extent of his interest in Telstra shareholdings from the Prime Minister, the Senate and the Australian people.

The first offence could not be more obvious. When Senator Parer was first exposed as having contravened the Prime Minister's code of conduct by holding shares in a company involved in the area of his portfolio responsibilities, what did Senator Parer do? He simply tried to resolve that breach by committing another breach. He divested himself of his shares and interests in the Parer family trust company, IMPL, but how did he divest? He divested to other family members constituted as White Rhinos Pty Ltd. What does the Prime Minister's code say about this dodge? It says this:
The transfer of interest to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.

So nothing could be clearer. How on earth can Senator Parer justify transferring his interest to yet another Parer family trust? This is the latest sham, the latest dodgy Parer family front company. You might ask why it is a company called White Rhinos. Perhaps it is because Senator Parer thinks that he is on the verge of political extinction, but I do not think that is the case. It was named White Rhinos because Senator Parer has an unbelievably thick hide. It might look like a rhino and it might walk and grunt like a rhino but it is really the Parer family trust, IMPL.

The second offence of Senator Parer is equally clear-cut. The Prime Minister wrote to all his ministers and instructed them not to purchase Telstra shares within 90 days of the float. That applied to all his ministers. What did Senator Parer do? He got in on the ground floor and purchased 2,600 shares in the float through his family trust vehicle, IMPL. It was an entity of which he was a then director and in which he held eight of the nine shares. He did that notwithstanding the fact that the Prime Minister said it was not acceptable for a minister to purchase shares in the name of a spouse, nominee or trust.

Finally, when Senator Parer decided to come clean on the extent of his many and varied interests, why did he choose to reveal only the 2,200 Telstra shares purchased by Spanlex, one of his three family trust structures? It was a purchase he claimed was okay because Spanlex was controlled by his wife. Why did he say nothing about the other 5,000 shares that Spanlex purchased in its capacity as a trustee of the Rutherglen superannuation fund? He also concealed the purchase of the 2,600 Telstra shares through IMPL and 3,000 shares in Gashbah. I will tell you why: this minister is a serial offender, a compulsive avoider and a compulsive dissembler. He has no regard for codes of conduct and the like. He has no propriety in the conduct of his ministerial responsibility.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have listened for, I assume, nearly five minutes to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.
—What is your point of order?

—If Senator Cook listened and stopped interjecting, he might get to hear the point of order. I have now listened for nearly five minutes to Senator Faulkner's speech. The whole speech has been peppered with accusations that reflect very adversely on the minister. With respect, Madam Deputy President, you have sat there with a smirk on your face from time to time.
—Excuse me, Senator.

—I suggest to you, Madam Deputy President, that when you are in the chair as the Deputy President trying to retain order in the Senate it would be appropriate for you to ask the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate not to breach the standing orders. He said that the minister is guilty of offences; that he has a thick hide; that he is involved in shams; and that he is a compulsive avoider. I remind you, Madam Deputy President, that just the other day I was required to withdraw an allegation against a senator opposite that he had an appalling track record. That is all I said, and I was required to withdraw it. If we are going to have those standards in this Senate, that is fine and I will abide by them. However, I suggest, with respect, that you ought to call Senator Faulkner to order.

—On the point of order: I do not think it is up to rank and file senators in the Senate to interpret the way that you look, Madam Deputy President. You have shown tolerance in the chair. I am certain that Senator Alston rejects his interjections from the back bleachers, which are normally crunched by a chair. You showed tolerance for him when he was standing right up in the back and interjecting. That was fair enough; you let it flow. The basic thrust of Senator Abetz's comments are insulting to you and the chair. It is not up to senators to interpret what you may be doing. I certainly did not observe you particularly enjoying Senator Faulkner's contribution or otherwise. I think you were just doing the normal job of the chair in this place. It is very easy to pick out a chair from the opposite side, criticise them and have a lash at them, but it does not add to the dignity of the chamber.

—Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: I must say that I thought what Senator Faulkner was saying was a bit of a joke as well, so I could understand if you had a smile on your face. Apart from that, on the substance of his delivery, it is not proper to make the accusation. It is certainly legitimate for Senator Faulkner to be developing his case but, if he wants to accuse Senator Parer of an improper behaviour, then there is a different course of action that is open to him. To do otherwise is to reflect upon him contrary to that which is allowed under the standing orders.
—Your jackboot dictatorship.
—Order! Senator Ray, would you care to withdraw that please?
—Jackboot dictatorship?
—You have to say please to Robert, do you?
—Senator Ferguson, you are not helping the situation.
—If offence was given, I withdraw unconditionally, but I do point out that we cannot even move a notice of motion in this place to take up Senator Hill's offer.
—That is what is called democracy. When Senator Ray had the numbers, he had no hesitation in wielding them to suit his purpose but of course it is now very different; he is in opposition.
—It was a lot easier too.

—And it was a lot easier because he used to get the Australian Democrats to roll over whenever needed. Apart from that, Madam Deputy President, I am suggesting to you seriously that the technique that is being adopted by Senator Faulkner in this debate is contrary to the standing orders and he should be obliged to debate the issue and not make the accusation.
—On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: I think it is perfectly clear that the standing orders do not allow personal imputations to be cast against senators.
—You ought to talk.

—Well, you can take an objection any time you like and we will deal with it. The standing orders do not preclude Senator Faulkner from characterising particular behaviour in a certain way, and of course he is capable of doing that in spades. But Senator Ray nodded in agreement and said, `Yes, that is exactly what is occurring.' Senator Faulkner was indeed casting personal aspersions against Senator Parer and that is why he did not get up and take any objection to that. He basically dealt with a fringe issue but he did not address the substance of Senator Abetz's complaint, because Senator Ray acknowledged across the chamber that Senator Faulkner was doing exactly that. Senator Ray knows that you are not allowed to do it. He did not quarrel with the proposition that you should not do it. He simply talked about other matters. The fact is that Senator Faulkner ought to be restricted by the standing orders and not allowed to simply come in here and time and again crawl in the gutter and trot out statements about an individual rather than that individual's behaviour.

—Senator Faulkner, you did use the words `compulsive dissembler', which does reflect upon the minister and I would ask you to withdraw that. Senator Abetz, I will get to you after Senator Faulkner has withdrawn.
—I withdraw.

—Senator Abetz, I did not appreciate your reflections upon the chair and I would appreciate it if you ceased that and did not repeat it in the future. If you are prepared to withdraw it, I would be most appreciative.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you. I call Senator Faulkner.
—Of course, Senator Parer will not do these things. He will not be expected to, with a gormless leader like Mr Howard. He knows he will get away with it.
—Senator Faulkner, would you please withdraw that.
—Is `gormless' unparliamentary?
—Yes.
—Well, I withdraw it. With a weak and snivelling leader like Mr Howard—
—Senator Faulkner, please!
—Is `weak' unparliamentary?
—No—
—I will not withdraw that.
—You used another word.
—Is `snivelling' unparliamentary, Madam Deputy President?
—It is a reflection.
—If it is unparliamentary, I will withdraw it. With a weak leader like Mr Howard, Senator Parer probably will get away with it. He should not. He should resign.

—Isn't it amazing that, once the standing orders are applied rigorously against the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner), he can hardly get a speech out? That is the thing that has characterised—
—Order! Senator Abetz, do not reflect upon another senator. Please continue.

—Thank you. That is the thing that has unfortunately been characteristic of opposition attacks in recent times; they use unparliamentary language which is clearly in breach of standing order 193(3). I would have thought that today, with the gallery full and with the broadcast sign on, the Labor Party may have used question time to deal with the issues that this nation faces, such as unemployment. But of course they do not want to touch unemployment because, if we were to talk about unemployment, we would be reminding them of their abysmal record.

speech.para: What about budget deficits? That is another important issue. They do not want to talk about budget deficits. Why? Because we would be pointing out the $10.5 billion deficit they left to us. We could talk about industrial relations, but they do not want to talk about industrial relations because they are all former trade union officials and they do what the trade unions tell them to do, irrespective of what is within the best interests of the nation. They do not want to talk about waterfront reform because, in their 13 years of government, they failed to deal with the issues.

They do not want to talk about the Natural Heritage Trust that we established because it has been such a great success in restoring the environment of this country. They do not want to talk about welfare fraud, which they presided over but which the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, has so systematically cleaned up. They do not want to talk about the Asian currency crisis. They do not want to talk about the drug strategy of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). They do not want to talk about the new Job Network. What do they want to talk about? A minister and his personal investments. All they are trying to do is to besmirch a minister who is respected by everybody on this side as being honest, very capable and a man of integrity.

I think the Labor Party realise that, over the past few days, they have taken a beating, especially in regional Australia, in relation to the issue of native title. They realise that the intervention in the debate of their former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who was the architect of the failed Native Title Act 1993, which has now been shown to be so full of holes, has occasioned them great embarrassment. They do not want to talk about Aboriginal affairs or native title. So what do they do? They go on an attack on an individual minister because he happens to have some wealth.

The Labor Party have to come clean in relation to the issue of policy. Where are their policies? They have no policies in those fundamental areas of unemployment, budget deficits, industrial relations, and so the list goes on. So what do they do? They concentrate all their efforts, every single question in question time today, on the purchase of Telstra shares by a member of Senator Parer's family.

At the same time—and the people of Australia might be interested in this—there are two senators sitting opposite who took full advantage and purchased Telstra shares. What is more, they have a senator sitting opposite who, in fact, runs a family trust—something which they accuse the minister of doing. They have a senator over there who runs a family trust and they have two senators over there who have bought Telstra shares, yet somehow, because they have this complete vacuum in the area of policy, they are trying to distract attention from their own policy deficits. Their attack on Senator Parer will reflect very badly on them in the weeks to come. We on this side have great confidence in Senator Parer. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We have all heard of the saying: the rich get richer and the poor get poorer. The performance of Senator Parer in this affair is of one who believes in at least the first part of that saying. He is one of the wealthiest members of this parliament, and he could not resist an opportunity to accrete further wealth to himself and to his family through a complex series of personal trusts, of which he will ultimately be the beneficiary.

speech.para: It does not matter how inappropriate his actions are. It does not matter how seemly they are. It does not matter if they defy the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). We know that, in this case, they defied the Prime Minister and specifically a letter from the Prime Minister to all of his ministers, of whom Senator Parer is a prominent one, saying that they should not purchase Telstra shares. Nothing is going to stand in the way of this minister's dash for cash. What did he do? He dived in and, through a complex series of trusts, made sure that he was a significant beneficiary.

Let us go immediately to the facts here. The fact here on trial is of a minister whose public office is being confused with his private gain. That is a fundamental flaw in this system. Ministers should be above reproach. This minister is not, and I will demonstrate it. First of all, this minister has form. He had his hand in the till before.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Cook!
—I withdraw.
—Well, don't say it in the first place, you troll!
—Order! Senator Ferguson, would you withdraw that as well, please.
—I withdraw.

—When he was minister before, he held shares in companies in his own portfolio over which he has control of policy. That was in clear breach of the Prime Minister's guidelines. That was in breach of past practice in this place. If he did not actually obtain private gain, and we are not sure of that, it certainly breached the principle that justice must be seen to be done, because in this case it was not.

speech.para: He defied the Prime Minister because he purchased shares in Telstra within the 90-day period after the float. What does that mean? The Prime Minister said in his letter that you cannot buy them in your own name, in your spouse's name or in the name of a nominee or a trust. I would have thought that was clear enough, but he has obtained shares which go to his own pecuniary interest. Let us go to the record. Mrs Parer got 2,200 shares. IMPL, as a trustee of the W.R. Parer family trust, got 2,600 shares. Gashbah, a Parer family company, got 3,000 shares. Spanlex, a trustee of the W.R. Parer family trust No. 2, got 2,200 shares.
