The advice I have been given has been acknowledged around the chamber as being very good advice—and that is the advice from McCarthy QC and Kildea of the New South Wales bar.

speech.para: I did confer with Senator Minchin yesterday evening about the implications of the Federal Court decision. The minister informed me that this legislation—as I think everybody around the chamber realises—does not have any specific effect on the native title rights and interests of successful claimants, as found by Olney J. That was my view—and it was my initial view without anything being said.

I did, however, indicate to the minister that it was my desire he should take immediate steps to consult with the persons directly concerned, the native titleholders—and let me remind the chamber that that is only the third case to have succeeded since the coming into force of the 1993 Native Title Act; of all the applicants for native title status, it is only the third to have succeeded. It is unbelievable, but that is the case. It is indicative, of course, that the 1993 act is not fully working to the benefit of the indigenous people of Australia, which is what I have been saying all along.

The minister did say that he would—and he has repeated here that he will—consult with indigenous people and their representatives to determine what procedures or procedural rights, further than those that are currently in the act, would be necessary for offshore areas. I acknowledge, and I would be the first to do so, that complex areas are involved, and that the minister has the responsibility to have discussion not only with indigenous people and their representatives who are directly implicated and concerned but also with other stakeholders in the area—say, professional fishermen and others of that sort. However, he also really has a duty as the minister to consult with the states.

I think we are probably acting prematurely if we adopt the resolution that is before the chamber. I think that is the reasonable way to go about it—the way that the minister has indicated to the committee previously. We will all be very interested in the outcome.

talk.start.para: —Using commonsense, one would have thought, and I am sure most Australians would think, that the Croker Island decision, which gives recognition to native title over the seas, includes the fisheries which the people of that region have used forever. That would mean that, if some other commercial operation moved in, they would be able to ward that off. But the act as it stands says that the giving of a licence to exploit those fisheries is valid provided the indigenous people—and there is only one provision—have been given an opportunity to comment. That is all. So you go and ask them to comment on the giving of this licence which exploits their fisheries to their loss and which does not recognise that those fisheries are theirs for commercial exploitation as well as for their indigenous fishing. You take that away and substitute it with a right to comment on what happens in the future.

speech.para: Has it been worth their getting recognition of their claim? They are left with a right to comment. That is what these amendments are trying to correct—to at least give them the right to be recognised as having a native title interest which extends to a potential commercial interest in so far as those fisheries are concerned. That is what happens in Canada, that is what happens in New Zealand, but that is what patently does not happen here. This reduces the indigenous people to commentators on the loss of their own resources.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I spoke at some little length previously about the procedural rights that will attach to native title both in the intertidal zone and offshore. We believe those rights are appropriate, and our belief is certainly reinforced by the actual content of the native title decision made by Justice Olney. These are very limited rights. They are rights to hunt and fish and access for traditional purposes—in other words, non-commercial purposes. It specifically said `non-commercial purposes'.

speech.para: We believe in those circumstances the provisions set out both in the current Native Title Act and the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] are appropriate. You must set in place and the relevant government that proposes to issue a permit, lease or licence to do something offshore must grant to any native title holders corresponding rights. That was the scheme set out and approved by the Senate in 1993. We believe it remains appropriate. Nothing in the Croker Island decision changes our view about what is the appropriate set of procedural rights. Indeed, we have gone beyond that in respect of procedural rights in relation to the regulation or management of offshore waters and living aquatic resources.

We specifically said that the native title holders, claimants and relevant representative bodies must be notified and must be given an opportunity to comment on such grants—those that are not found in the current Native Title Act and not found at common law. We have specifically provided a set of procedural rights essentially equating to freehold rights in the intertidal zone. We believe, contrary to what is being said, that we have quite specifically set out an adequate, appropriate, fair, reasonable and equitable set of procedural rights for activities proposed offshore that may have some impact on native title.

talk.start.para: —That is not contrary to what I said; that corroborates it. The indigenous people do not have commercial rights, and they have the right to comment when commercial fishers move in on their traditional fishing grounds. I hate this process; I hate this outcome. I hate this process of erosion of the rights of indigenous people, and I hate most of all the disempowering of indigenous people of this country through this deliberated process. There are no accidents occurring here. This is with intent by the government and Senator Harradine. It is a disempowerment of the indigenous people. If ever there was a case in point, here it is. It is the interests of the commercial operators that are being looked after. As I said earlier in the piece, it is a case of determinedly bringing in the dictum that the first shall be last and the last shall be first. The first Australians are being put very definitely last here.

speech.para: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

talk.start.para: —Order! Applause from either the floor of the chamber or the gallery is disorderly. I would ask people to remember that and maintain order, which has been very well maintained until now.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I would note that the advances in common law native title in the last six years have been quite extraordinary and very significant for Aboriginal people, with the Mabo decision itself in 1992 and then the Wik decision doubling the area of Australia over which native title may be found in 1996, and now in 1998 expanded yet again to include offshore. I think we should all reflect upon that. These are quite significant advances in a remarkable six-year period.

speech.para: We have had to put in place legislatively the appropriate procedural rights that should attach to this growing area of Australia that is potentially subject to findings of native title. We are responding adequately in our view. I have indicated both privately and publicly to Senator Harradine that, while we believe we have adequately provided for a set of procedural rights attaching to native title offshore, the government will very willingly discuss with the parties, as this act beds down and as the common law in relation to native title offshore develops, the adequacy and appropriateness of the procedural rights with all parties affected, including the fishing and aquaculture industries, the relevant governments that are involved and the indigenous people involved to ensure that we maintain adequate procedures. I give that undertaking, and I will ensure that that happens. But the government is certainly not convinced that there need be any change to this bill.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the Australian Greens amendment AH2 be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —We will now move to Greens amendment AH3.

interjection.para: (AH3) Amendment H22, after "forms" (second occurring), insert ", other than water below the high water mark and living aquatic resources in those waters,".

talk.start.para: —The question now is that committee agree to the amendments made by the House to the bill.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: That the following report from the committee be adopted:
The committee has resolved not to insist on the amendments made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives had disagreed and has agreed to the amendments made by the House.

talk.start.para: —I have circulated an amendment standing in my name and that of Senator Woodley, Senator Brown and Senator Margetts. I move:

speech.para: At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate:

(a) expresses its concern that indigenous people were not consulted in the recent negotiations on the bill and notes from the statement issued by the National Indigenous Working Group on 7 July 1998 that indigenous people do not consent to the bill in its current form and have not endorsed the bill in any previous form; and
(b) notes the inadequacy of the bill to deal with the implications of the Federal Court's decision in the Croker Island case.

I wish to read into the Hansard the first two pages of the National Indigenous Working Group's statement, and my colleagues from the Democrats and the Greens will continue with the rest of that statement. This is a statement issued by the National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title on behalf of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia:

The National Indigenous Working Group considers that the commentary and judgments expressed in this statement are a true and accurate reflection of the opinions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples as can be expressed at the national level.
The National Indigenous Working Group affirms that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is an active participant in the Working Group.
We, the members of the National Indigenous Working Group, reject entirely the Native Title Amendment Bill as currently presented before the Australian Parliament.

We confirm that we have not been consulted in relation to the contents of the current Bill, particularly in regard to the agreement negotiated between the Prime Minister and Senator Harradine, and that we have not given consent to the Bill in any form which might be construed as sanction to its passage into Australian law.
We have endeavoured to contribute during the past two years to the public deliberations of Native Title entitlements in Australian law.

Our participation has not been given the legitimacy by the Australian Government that we expected, and we remain disadvantaged and aggrieved by the failure of the Australian Government to properly integrate our expert counsel into the lawmaking procedures of government.

We are of the opinion that the Bill will amend the Native Title Act 1993 to the effect that the Native Title Act can no longer be regarded as a fair law or a law which is of benefit to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples.
We remind the Australian Government and the Australian Peoples that the Native Title Act is not the mechanism which creates our ownership of land, waters and environment.

Our ownership derives from our ancient title which precedes colonisation of this continent and our ownership must continue, in Australian law, to be recognised in accordance with our indigenous affiliation with the land, waters and environment.

Our relationship with the land, waters and environment is a complex arrangement of spiritual, social, political and economic associations with the land which cannot be replicated, substituted, replaced or compensated.

We regard fair and equal treatment of our indigenous land rights, or Native Title, in comparison to the land title of other Australians, to be determined by the level of respect and regard for the titles and not by the assimilation of titles.

It is therefore a fundamental flaw of the Australian Government to consider that fairness or equality in the Native Title Act has been achieved by limiting the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, for example to the rights of pastoral lessees.
On this basis we reject as repugnant the proposal that the Native Title rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people must now be reduced where pastoral leases occur.
We also consider the requirement that we must prove contemporary physical association with our land to be unacceptable.

Although the Australian Government has sought means to "soften" the impact of this requirement, it nevertheless limits our Common Law rights, and it deliberately lessens our access to lands, waters and environment.

The invidious intent of the "physical association" test is to validate the past "locked gate" policies of the pastoralists, to exploit the 100-years imprisonment of our people under the "reserves" system, and to despoil the rights of the "Stolen Generation".

We are absolutely of the view that the Native Title Act, once it is amended, will no longer reflect the negotiated outcomes of 1993, when Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people did participate in the construction of the statute, and ultimately agreed to the implementation of that law.
That is the first two pages of the statement. Senator Margetts or Senator Woodley may wish to read out the next two pages.

talk.start.para: —In speaking in support of the amendment to the motion I will use the words of the National Indigenous Working Group because this is the only chance they have had to be involved in this debate:

speech.para: The agreement was founded upon basic principles which are no longer maintained. These principles include:
• the legislation would not preempt or alter Common Law definition of Native Title;
• the Commonwealth retained responsibility for Native Title procedures and instruments; and
• the Racial Discrimination Act would apply, except in the situation of validation of grants of interests over Native Title from 1975 to 1994.
We remain concerned that the Australian Government has ignored its commitments to implement a "social justice package" for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as a compensatory measure.

We are also concerned that existing and relevant measures for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples such as ATSIC, heritage protection laws, the Indigenous Land Corporation, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation are being seriously eroded and impaired.

These measures have been developed by the Australian Government in a non partisan approach to mitigating the effects of past colonisation and racial exploitation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

We are offended by the extremely partisan approach of the current Australian Government which has caused the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples to be political victims, subjected to racial vilification by some Australian institutions and citizens.

This vilification has, in the opinion of the Working Group, been incited by the Australian Government's bent to denigrate Native title rights, and has not been adequately addressed by the Australian Government under the goal of eradicating racial prejudice.
My colleague Senator Brown will continue.

talk.start.para: —The National Indigenous Working Group's historic statement of rejection continues:

speech.para: We remind the Australian Government of the international standards on human rights which it has failed to observe in the making of this new Native Title law.
The Australian Government signed in 1979 the "Lusaka Declaration of the Commonwealth on Racism and Racial Discrimination".
Under the terms of this declaration the Australian Government accepted an international responsibility of governments to work together to eradicate racial discrimination.
The statement, in part, reads . . . .

We attach particular importance to ensuring that children shall be protected from practices which may foster racism or racial prejudice. Children have the right to be brought up and educated in a spirit of tolerance and understanding so as to be able to contribute to the building of future societies based on justice and friendship.
We believe those groups who may be especially disadvantaged because of residual racist attitudes are entitled to the fullest protection of the law.
We recognise the history of the Commonwealth and its diversity require that special attention should be paid to the problems of indigenous minorities . . .

We agree that special measures may in particular circumstances be required to advance the development of disadvantaged groups in society. We recognise that the effects of colonialism or racism in the past may make desirable special provisions for the social and economic enhancement of indigenous populations.

Inspired by the principles of freedom and equality which characterise our associations, we accept the solemn duty of working together to eliminate racism and racial prejudice. This duty involves the acceptance of the principle that positive measures may be required to advance the elimination of racism, including assistance to those struggling to rid themselves and their environment of the practice.

Being aware that legislation alone cannot eliminate racism and racial prejudice, we endorse the need to initiate public information and education policies designed to promote understanding, tolerance, respect and friendship among peoples and racial groups.

We are particularly conscious of the importance of the contribution the media can make to human rights and the eradication of racism and racial prejudice by helping to eliminate ignorance and misunderstanding between people and by drawing attention to the evils which afflict humanity. We affirm the importance of truthful presentation of facts in order to ensure that the public are fully informed of the dangers presented by racism and racial prejudice.

talk.start.para: —The voice of the indigenous people continues:

speech.para: The Working Group is not intimidated from speaking of racial discrimination in the Native Title legislation.
We are guided by the United Nations definition of "racial discrimination" as it is defined in the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

The Australian Government has ratified this Convention by enactment of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. This legislation is fundamental to the proper treatment of Native Title interests by all Australian governments.

We consider that the Australian Government should recall its intention to meet international standards on human rights, and must renew its commitment to respect these standards in domestic law and other dealings.
Article 1.1 of the Convention describes "racial discrimination" as meaning:

any distinction, exclusion, restriction or preference based on race, colour, descent, or national or ethnic origin which has the purpose or effect of nullifying or impairing the recognition, enjoyment or exercise, on an equal footing, of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the political, economic, social, cultural or any other field of public life.

Under the terms of the ratified Convention the Australian Government "undertakes to engage in no act or practice of racial discrimination against persons, groups of persons or institutions" [Article 2.1(b)] and "to adopt immediate and positive measures designed to eradicate all incitement to, or acts of, such discrimination". [Article 4]

The National Indigenous Working Group is disappointed that the Australian Government has relegated the position of the Working Group to one of opposition to the Government and, in this situation, the Australian Government has not endeavoured to address the concerns of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples regarding racial discrimination.

The National Indigenous Working Group is extremely disappointed that the Australian Government has failed to confront the issues of discrimination in the Native Title laws and implicitly provoked the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples to pursue concerns through costly and time-consuming litigation, rather than through negotiation.

We particularly condemn the Prime Minister, the Hon. John Howard, for his personal failure to display leadership to the parliament, to vested interests, to Australian citizens, and to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples for a just and reconciled nation by the Year 2001.

talk.start.para: —This is the final part of the statement from the Indigenous Working Group:

speech.para: We consider that the Prime Minister holds an obligation through his high office to personally advocate the principles of freedom and equality for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, and to personally campaign for the elimination of ignorance and misunderstanding between peoples.
Finally the National Indigenous Working Group notes that much attention has been given to Senator Harradine and Senator Colston to defeat the Native Title Amendment Bill.
While we continue to urge these individuals to respect our position on the legislation and oppose the Bill, we do not intend to amplify their roles in relation to all parliamentarians.

The National Indigenous Working Group does thank Senator Harradine for his staunch support of the Native Title Act 1993, recognising his role in strengthening that legislation, and on his principled stands during the previous Senate considerations of the Native Title Amendment Bill.

However we remind Senator Harradine and all parliamentarians that Australian history is in the making, and that future generations will be examining today's actions in the context of justice towards Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples.

History will not record the technical details of draft legislation, but will record the outcomes of the legislation and whether Australia faced up to its long term neglect or turned back the clock on reconciliation.

We insist that our children and their descendants enjoy their lawful rights as revealed in the 1992 High Court decision on the "Mabo" case. We also insist that our children be safeguarded from the same racism, racial prejudice, and racial vilification which we are experiencing today.

We are determined that the future generations of Australian society are raised and educated in a spirit of tolerance and understanding which will ensure that the measures of justice important to the reconciliation between our peoples can be appreciated and embraced.
We call upon all parliamentarians to give serious thought to the responsibility of the Australian Government to eradicate racial discrimination in this country.

The National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title absolutely opposes the Native Title Amendment Bill, calls upon all parliamentarians to cast their vote against this legislation, and invites the Australian Government to open up immediate negotiations with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples for coexistence between the Indigenous Peoples and all Australians.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The government, not surprisingly, I guess, opposes this amendment to the motion. I must say I have enjoyed my dealings with the National Indigenous Working Group in the almost 2½ years I have been dealing with native title. They may not have enjoyed dealing with me, but I have certainly appreciated their robust putting forward of their case.

speech.para: It must be remembered that, essentially, the National Indigenous Working Group, to which this amendment refers and the statement of which has been read into the Hansard, is essentially made up of the professional officers of a number of Aboriginal land councils around Australia, the membership of which does seem to change from time to time. They do not actually have any right to speak on behalf of all indigenous people, as this amendment proclaims. We are asked to note that the Indigenous Working Group says that `indigenous people do not consent to the bill'. With due respect to the National Indigenous Working Group and its operation, the fact is that it has no right to claim that it speaks for all indigenous people in Australia. It is quite an extraordinary claim for it to make. It is not elected by the indigenous people. It does not speak on behalf of all indigenous people. To simply make the claim which you want to make with this amendment that all indigenous people do not consent to this bill is quite extraordinary.

There is also the extraordinary proposition in this that somehow we are meant to assume that legislation affecting Aboriginal people can pass this parliament only if it is consented to by the Indigenous Working Group, one presumes. In other words, they are to have a veto on any legislation passing this parliament—a proposition which I would have thought would be quite unacceptable to the opposition. To suggest that any group should have any veto over legislation passed by the duly elected parliament of this country is quite obnoxious.

The statement has been made that they were not consulted. As I have said before, time and time again, the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself went through an enormous period of consultation following the Wik decision. He was criticised for the time he was taking to reach a conclusion as to the appropriate legislative response to the Wik decision.

But what we were dealing with just recently was a situation where Senator Harradine approached the government seeking discussions to resolve the dispute between the House of Representatives and the Senate. This was a parliamentary dispute between the Senate and the House of Representatives which the government, on behalf of the House of Representatives, and Senator Harradine had to discuss in some detail. That was what we sought to resolve.

Of course, Senator Harradine, as he will no doubt make clear, sought to put propositions to the government quite forcefully which were clearly on behalf of indigenous Australians. He sought to have the government accommodate propositions within the legislation which responded to the interests of Aboriginal Australians. To the extent that we have amended the legislation to accommodate Senator Harradine, those accommodations involve responding to the interests of Aboriginal Australians, as represented by Senator Harradine.

I understand the grievance that is felt apparently because this phase did not involve formal consultation, but it could not, as Senator Harradine has made clear. These were very difficult negotiations with Senator Harradine on a number of matters. As I say, Senator Harradine was putting propositions all of which involved representations on behalf of Aboriginal people, and all the amendments that we put forward involved accommodating those particular interests.

I have said repeatedly that it is a complete furphy which the government does not accept that somehow the inadequacy of the bill is exposed by the decision in the Croker case. Quite the contrary. The bill more than adequately deals with the implications of that case. Clearly, the bill has been prepared with considerable foresight in that it accommodates that decision more than adequately. The government completely opposes this amendment.
Could I just suggest to the Senate that leave be granted for the proposal of the adjournment of the Senate to be deferred until the conclusion of this item of business?
Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —Could I have the leave of the Senate to conclude my remarks, which should be only 10 minutes, before the adjournment is proposed?
—Is leave granted for Senator Harradine to do that and for the adjournment to be deferred for 10 minutes for that purpose?
—Senator Harradine, there is about one minute this evening before we adjourn.
—Was leave not granted?
—Leave was not granted.
—By whom? I have to respond, or are you gagging me?
—Order! Leave has not been granted for you to speak beyond 10.30 p.m.
—Order! It being nearly 10.30 p.m., pursuant to standing orders, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the adjournment debate. The matter I wish to raise is one that relates to quite a number of voters—Australian citizens—who have taken the time, effort and opportunity to contact my office in respect of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] before the chamber. I feel it is appropriate to note the thoughts of one of the many voters who place significance in what happens here and in what is said here.

speech.para: Disgusted with the response of the government in general and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in particular to the National Sorry Day, one such person wrote to the Prime Minister, to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). Her name is Megan Evans—she does not mind her name being used—and this is her story. This is what she wrote to the ministers:
I haven't signed the Sorry Book. It seemed to me to be too small a thing to do to express a very big feeling.
My husband was one of the stolen children.
He was a year younger than me.
I'm sorry.

I'm sorry that when I was a child of seven, wearing party dresses and carrying my suitcase to school, he was regularly being beaten with a strop strap at a Children's Home and running away by hanging underneath a train all the way from Sale in Gippsland to Richmond station.
I'm sorry that his mother died in 1988, the year of the bicentennial, at the age of 46 and I am lucky enough to still have the company of my mother at the age of 75.
I'm sorry that I am about to embark on my 8th year of tertiary education and he had to study for his HSC from books begged for in jail.
I'm sorry that he was 9 years old when his mother was eligible to vote, having some small say in a future on his behalf, yet my parents took that right for granted for all of their life and mine.

Most of all I am sorry that I couldn't ever know his pain or do anything that would take it away. He used to say that he just wished someone from the government would apologise for the mess they had made of his life.
I am sorry that he died a lonely and painful death with a noose tied around his neck in 1993, the International Year of the Worlds Indigenous Peoples.

I am sorry that the legislators of today have listened little and understood even less. The stories of the stolen generations were an indictment before the world of the attitudes and behaviour of mainstream Australia and its governments over many years. The bill that we have been discussing in the last two days in its substance, and in the poisonous process that has brought it back to this place, explains why this government can never say sorry. They just don't get it.

talk.start.para: —The current debate on migration has focused on the numbers of migrants arriving, rather than on the undoubted contribution they have made to Australian society as a whole. Australia is a melting pot of people whose ancestors have come from just about every country in the world. What has been overlooked in the present debate about multiculturalism is the great capacity of newcomers to adapt their own distinctive culture to their new environment. It is this capacity that has helped develop Australia into the diverse and successful nation it is.

speech.para: To use a term coined by American author and commentator, Eric Liu, after a few gen erations the descendants of migrants become part of omniculturalism—not multiculturalism or monoculturalism but omniculturalism. In the process of adaptation to a different culture, many of the values and principles held dear by the original migrants—values and principles brought with them from their country of origin—evolve to suit the environment in which they are in. Thus the move to omniculturalism is more about finding new values and principles than it is about losing old ones.

Unfortunately, the adaptation process is often made harder than it might otherwise be through the cynical use of identity politics. There is no better example of this than the Asian migration debate, a debate which Ms Pauline Hanson and her One Nation Party are using to peddle misinformation on which they are basing their policies. Ms Hanson and her closest supporters are utilising the traditional methods of all bigots by using exaggeration, manipulation and bodgie figures to exploit the fears and insecurities of others about Australia's intake of Asian migrants.

Let us look at some of the facts. In 1996-97, the intake from Asian countries was 32,084 out of a total of 85,752. This represents 37 per cent, not the 70 per cent claimed by One Nation. In the 1996 census, 2.6 per cent of the Australian population was born in South-East Asia, 1.4 per cent in North-East Asia and 0.8 per cent in southern Asia. Therefore, the total percentage of the Australian population that was born in Asia at the time of the census was 4.8 per cent. The ABS predicts that, by 2040, seven per cent of Australians will have been born in Asia.

Ms Hanson and her immigration spokesperson, Ms Robin Spencer, claim the official figures are wrong and are lies being perpetrated by the government. But the figures that One Nation have used have been disputed by the demographer who collated them, Dr Charles Price, who has stated, `They've never asked me what I think. They've just taken my writings and put their own interpretations.' What credibility can One Nation have, particularly when Ms Hanson fails to take into account the fact that these are not government figures. They were official ABS figures to which the government has no input and where the information is objectively gathered. The Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday, 4 July, summed it up aptly when it said:

. . . in the case of One Nation, an unwillingness to acknowledge the facts and to take them into account when framing policies when they do not fit the prejudices of Ms Hanson seems to be the defining metaphor of the party.

Another problem with the current debate is that, when talking of Asian migration, all nations in the region tend to be lumped together as one huge mass of people who are all alike. Of course, nothing could be further from the truth. In broad terms, Asian migration includes arrivals from countries as diverse as India, Laos, Indonesia and Cambodia. Nevertheless, in the migration debate, all such people are identified simply as Asian.

The ethnic identities of newcomers from these countries are removed by applying a commonality to them all. Eric Liu, in his recently released book entitled The Accidental Asian: Notes of a Native Speaker looks at identity politics and makes a number of pertinent observations. He makes the point that:

Unlike blacks, Asians do not have a cultural idiom that arose from centuries of thinking of themselves as a race; unlike Jews, Asians haven't got a unifying spiritual and historical legacy; unlike Latinos, another recently invented community, Asians continued their apartness.

Apart from indigenous Australians, we in Australia are all migrants or descendants of migrants. As such, descendants of migrants are to be found everywhere, and in most cases it is impossible to ascertain from which country their ancestors came. We are Australian in every sense of the word. This is because, in general, newcomers realise that to try to set up in Australia an exact replica of a community they left is largely unworkable. It also defeats the very purpose of their migration—to take advantage of new opportunities as part of starting a new life.

Opponents point to suburbs where certain races are said to dominate as proof of their assertion that migration leads to ethnic ghettos. It is true that many newly arrived migrants tend to gravitate towards others from their old country. Obviously new arrivals must find their way and often it is others with a similar ethnic, social or religious background who can provide them with the road signs they need to negotiate their new homeland.

Opponents of migration also point out that most migrants choose to live in urban areas rather than help to develop less populated areas. If this is so, the fault lies not with migrants but with policies over generations that have failed to provide sufficient opportunities and incentives to encourage migrants to settle in areas outside the better known urban belts. Infrastructure and jobs are necessary to act as a magnet to draw migrants to where they are needed most.

Migrants do, of course, move out of cities and help develop rural and regional areas. A fine example of this are the German settlers in the Barossa Valley who helped develop a wine industry that is now internationally recognised. So, too, in Griffith, New South Wales, where Italian migrants established market gardens which continue to serve people throughout the nation. Many of the families are now third or fourth generation and rightly call themselves Australians—not Italian-Australians, just Australians.

More frequently, successive generations do not want to cling to an ethnic past that was never really their own in the first place. It might have been their grandparents', but it is not theirs. In his book, Mr Liu looks at the United States experience and concludes that the so-called Asian-American identity is both contrived and unnecessary.

Mr Liu's observations may be as relevant to Australia as they are to the United States. In the debate over Asian migration it is often overlooked that many shirk the industry that has sprung up around newcomers promoting an Asian identity and instead seek immediately to adapt. In describing this very situation for a person of Asian descent who strives to assimilate, Mr Liu has said in respect of himself that he had been described by other Asians as a banana—yellow on the outside, white on the inside.

Marriages to people of different racial or ethnic backgrounds often result from the adaptation process. In the United States, for instance, 34 per cent of Asians are married to non-Asians, giving rise to hyphenated bloodlines that see third or fourth generation people having an ancestry of ethnic combinations such as Chinese, Scottish, Irish and Jew. The combinations are almost endless and show once again that the concept of omniculturalism is a reality, not just a theory.

There are dangers in the current situation in Australia, and as a nation we must be careful to temper this current debate. With inflammatory and totally inaccurate statements being made almost on a daily basis by One Nation, we could, unless we are careful, force Asian migrants into what Mr Liu describes as the `enclave mentality'.
Omniculturalism will eventually see the breakdown of race as an issue. Mr Liu argues that race is fundamentally an invention. He wrote:
And just as something can be invented, so it can be dismantled. If you believe in the identity, I can respect that. I'm just not sure it will last another generation.

While it might be drawing a long bow to say that race is an invention, it is fair to argue that the so-called Asian invasion of our cities is an invention and a myth. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, has refuted the myths and given the correct figures as opposed to the bodgie ones being touted by One Nation. One Nation claims that the population is doubling when in fact without immigration it would simply be declining. But the myths continue to be capitalised upon by opponents to immigration who fail to see how skilled migrants can help to advance properly thought out national objectives.

Australia is a great nation because of its racial, political and religious diversity, which interacts well and thrives together. Omniculturalism reaches across the racial divide and provides unity in diversity. It is the very glue that makes Australia a vital and interesting place.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to respond to Senator Tambling's statement during the adjournment debate last night and his attempt to defend the record of the Northern Territory government. One might be led to believe that his response sounds more like `Travels with my Aunt'. It fails to provide this parliament with a true picture of what is happening in the Northern Territory.

speech.para: My role is to defend my constituents, who for too long have felt that, since the resignation of Bob Collins, their concerns have not been heard here in Canberra. Senator Tambling thinks that it is a bad habit of the Labor Party to take a different viewpoint. But that is our role. My role here is to ensure that the people in my electorate are well represented, not the Northern Territory government.

I am here to represent all sectors of the Northern Territory, not just the Northern Territory government and its interests. My role is to ensure that the voice of ordinary Territorians is heard—not just a few, not just the mining companies or the pastoralists, not just Aboriginals or big business, but all sectors.

Senator Tambling says that the Labor Party believes that we have an exclusive right to Aboriginal people, policy and development, and he refutes this. But let us look at some of the recent actions by the Country-Liberal Party in the Northern Territory. There has been no decision by that party to put One Nation last in the next federal election. The second Senate candidate for the Country-Liberal Party, an Aboriginal woman, has said on radio that, if they give their second preferences to One Nation, she may well reconsider her position on the ticket and whether or not she will stand.

The Chief Minister kissed and made up with Galarrwuy Yunupingu yesterday, but what sorts of principles and policies drive a person in a high, prominent public office such as the leader of the government to refer to a senior, well respected leader of Aboriginal people as a `whingeing, carping black' in the first place, simply because that person did not agree with the actions of the Northern Territory government?
Senator Tambling said last night in relation to yesterday's Federal Court decision on the native title sea rights—and I quote from Hansard, page 4263:

It is a pity we did not have that important determination before all of this native title debate began. It would have given us a much clearer vision, and certainly a clearer objective in dealing with many of the issues.

Yes, Senator Tambling, it is a pity. It is a pity that your government and the Northern Territory government did not consult with indigenous Territorians before entering into the debate in the chamber this week, and certainly these discussions should have been reviewed before the native title debate began. I am pleased to see that you have recognised this, but it is too late. The polls, contrary to what you say, show that Aboriginal people support the Labor Party. They know that we are not a party that will desert them, and we are not a party that will insult them but will look after them.

Senator Tambling also referred to the 13 years of Labor in government and tried to claim, without any relevant evidence, that there were no measurable achievements. Let us examine the figures and the facts. I should highlight that my colleague made no mention last night of the achievements by the Howard government with respect to the Northern Territory. Regional road allocation was cut by the federal government. Labor had committed $15 million to the Territory and had paid $5 million, but the coalition cut the program completely. This affects tourism, transport and outback properties in the Northern Territory. Regional universities have been cut by 4,700 places nationally and Abstudy has been cut by $38.7 million. This has had a major impact on Batchelor College, a tertiary institution that provides training for Aboriginal people, and the director of the college, whom I personally know, has spent many, many months negotiating a better deal for the college in the interests of his students.

The Northern Territory University has suffered cuts along with the rest of the universities of up to $624 million nationwide to their operating grants over four years. This has resulted in the loss of the English department from the Faculty of Arts and some courses and places from the Faculty of Technology. This government does not appreciate the role and the efforts of the Northern Territory University and how complex and demanding it is on a regional university to be what everybody wants it to be in an isolated place such as Darwin. This university could be a bonus.

Small and medium business development has been retarded. There has been a $4 billion assault on the industry assistance program and a $26 million cut to export assistance. Aboriginal communities were in their final stages of developing regional plans, but they were never completed due to funding cuts. Legal aid was cut by $120 million over three years. There is still no Medicare office in Katherine, and I have already mentioned many times since I entered this chamber the impact of the Cox Peninsula transmitter station being closed just after Labor had spent $13 million upgrading it.

Senator Tambling mentioned the record of achievement in the Northern Territory and made reference to the increase in population, which I hope has not been one that has been single-handedly owed to the Northern Territory government. The number of people employed in the Northern Territory has increased, but this is largely due to the programs and policies of the Labor government such as the decision to relocate the defence forces to Robertson Barracks. The average weekly earnings have increased in the Northern Territory and, again, this is due to the policies of the Labor government and the efforts of the unions through the national wage cases.

If you look closely at Hansard, I do not say that the Northern Territory has not developed. This is not true. The policies and attitude of the Northern Territory government have frustrated and retarded the economic development of the Northern Territory. Senator Tambling claims that this is wrong, but he has not proved anything to the contrary. In a week of national significance and a week of debate on the two most important issues affecting the Northern Territory in the last six months—Wik and Telstra—where is the voice of the Northern Territory government? Where is the voice of the CLP or Senator Tambling on these issues?

I do not oppose development, nor does the Labor Party. It is welcomed, but under the right conditions with all parties being consulted, their concerns listened to and all parties having a chance to negotiate an outcome that is satisfactory to everyone concerned. My role is to defend my constituents, to represent them and to make their voice heard in this chamber, particularly in times of national significance.

talk.start.para: —What an extraordinary contribution by Senator Crossin. I must say that I did not have the pleasure of hearing Senator Tambling last night, but I know that what he said would have been accurate because I know that he speaks for the people of the Northern Territory. After all, at least he has been elected by the people of the Northern Territory.

speech.para: The thing that really amused me about Senator Crossin's remarks was that she said that she represents all the people in the Northern Territory and they are totally opposed to the things that their Territory government is doing. That surprises me because, as I recall, the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory has been in government for the 20 years that the Territory has had self-government. If it is such a bad government, why don't the electors of the Northern Territory get rid of it? Each election, they re-elect it with increasing majorities. Of course, in the federal parliament we know that the two elected federal representatives from the Northern Territory are members of the coalition.

It has been a long, hard day and I do not want to keep the Senate too long. We have had to listen to a lot of pious hypocrisy from some of those opposing the government's position on the native title legislation, so we do not want to be held up with long adjournment speeches, but I was moved to speak because when I was with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in Maryborough last week a supporter of One Nation handed me a docu ment and said, `We don't like your 10-point plan; here's our 10-point plan.' It had nothing to do with native title; it was their 10 points on how the government of Australia should be run. I opened it up when I got back to Parliament House several days later and had a glance at what was in this note. I was struck by the similarities of the policies being advocated by the One Nation Party, the policies being advocated by the Labor Party and the policies being advocated by the Democrats.

Something from the Democrats was shoved under my door. It came through the mailbox or something. They are running some sort of campaign, but they listed a few things. That reinforced my view that, strangely enough in this world, the Labor Party, the Democrats and One Nation seem to have a lot of things in common. First of all, they all oppose the GST because they seem to like the current ramshackle wholesale sales tax system that is unfair, that favours the rich and that does nothing for Australia.

All three parties also, quite clearly, oppose our native title legislation and the amendments we have put to make that work for indigenous Australians and for all other Australians as well. All of the other parties oppose it. I suspect that One Nation oppose it for different reasons than the Labor Party and the Democrats but, again, it is a meeting of minds in opposition to that.

The other thing that struck me was in relation to tariffs. The Labor Party used to be quite sensible about tariffs but now they are taking some populist approach to economic activity, and they are starting to back-pedal on the question of tariffs. In that, they are totally at one with One Nation and the Australian Democrats. That concerns me because I come from North Queensland, an area which is dependant on the sugar industry. A lot of these people—the Labor Party, the Democrats and One Nation—are running around saying, `We should retaliate against Canada. We should ban imports of their pork.' They say that is needed to give Australian industry a fair go. Of course, in doing that, they are inviting retaliation from the Canadians, who purchase some $250 million worth of North Queensland sugar. Those are the sorts of policies that would really cripple the North Queensland and Australian sugar industries. But the Labor Party, the Democrats and One Nation are at one with that.

They also seem to be at one in opposing the full privatisation of Telstra. The Labor Party were the greatest privatising government in history—and congratulations to them, even though they did it very dishonestly. They used to go to an election saying, `We won't sell the Commonwealth Bank, we promise, hands on our hearts.' They would come in after the election and immediately do the opposite. With Telstra, even though their leader indicated several years ago that it should be sold, they are now thinking that there is an election issue there and they are going to oppose it.

It is the same with the Democrats, although I am not quite sure what their ideas on privatisation are. You see in their policy comments like `You can't sell the family silver,' so they seem to be opposed, and One Nation seems to be opposed. They say, `Don't sell off our public utilities.' The Labor Party, the Democrats and One Nation are the same in that none of them have any substantive arguments against the sale of Telstra. We believe Telstra should be sold because you can get a better telecommunications network for people in the country, you can get some money that will pay off debt run up by the Labor Party, and you can do a lot of good things. You also get governments out of running private commercial businesses which most sensible Australians would think they should be out of.

I then noticed that the Labor Party, the Democrats and One Nation, interestingly, are all opposed to the multilateral agreement on investment. I must say that the government is looking very carefully at this, and of course we will not be involved in anything that is bad for Australia, but it is interesting that One Nation supporters and Democrats supporters are at one in this particular area.

With immigration and population control, I am not sure what the Labor Party's policy is—in fact, it is very difficult to find out what the Labor Party's policy is on anything—but One Nation and the Democrats seem to have the same policy in relation to zero population growth. I suspect, in fairness, that they probably approach it from different angles, but if you are going to have zero population growth it does really mean one and the same thing.

As we get closer to the next election, I think the people of Australia are going to have a very clear choice. If they want a government that is devoted to genuine tax reform, if they want a government that wants to abolish an unfair tax system which favours the rich, if they want a government which will ensure increasing trade—and that of course means jobs, if they want a government that does not want to invite retaliatory trade barriers on our exports, if they want a government with a fair and just immigration policy, if they want a government that will give equity and certainty for all with native title, if they want a government that will provide a world class telecommunications system, if they want a government that will pay off foreign debt from the proceeds of the sale of a commercial enterprise and if they want decent good government, there is only one choice and that is for a return of the Liberal-National Party coalition government.

It is interesting that scrutiny shows that, in so many areas, the Labor Party and/or the Democrats and One Nation are the same in policy terms. They are the same on the GST, the same on the sale of Telstra, the same on protection of inefficient industries, the same on trade policy and, it appears, the same on immigration. It will be interesting, as we get into the election and see if the Labor Party has any policies and what they are, to compare how much they, the Democrats and One Nation are at one in a policy sense.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about the somewhat urgent problem of recycling and local government. Australian householders have a very good record of recycling and their diligence is increasing despite the common occurrence of lovingly sorted waste going off to landfill. Last week, a beverage industry study of 5,000 households in 98 council areas found that 72 per cent of beverage containers were being recycled—the highest recovery rate yet reported.

speech.para: The Australian Local Government Association estimates that 75 per cent of Australian households recycle. Whether it is transforming their milk cartons into Chinese boxes or separating their soft drink bottles from their aluminium cans, the appetite of Australian households for recycling is remarkable. This enthusiasm persists even in the knowledge that there is a glut in the market for recycled materials and many councils have actually given up their recycling programs because of the very poor returns. I think the enthusiasm for recycling bears out the maxim of thinking globally and acting locally. Faced with all sorts of environmental problems, the solutions of which are largely out of their hands, one of the very few positive actions that people can take is to sort out their own garbage.

Stopping uranium mining, global warming or industrial pollution seems out of reach for most people, as fighting these things and fighting against recalcitrant governments involves a lot of money. Recycling, I suspect, salves many a conscience. We all live in an unsustainable society which gives us few options to avoid colluding in environmental destruction. Choices are made for us through policies that make coal-fired electricity a cheaper short-term option for most people than renewable energy, and our hurried lifestyles and nuclear families have enshrined the cult of the disposable. I suppose we are all on the lookout to make a contribution no matter how small.

The sad news is that local government is now at breaking point in this struggle of having to bear most of the responsibility for recycling initiatives in this country. In Sydney, for instance, household paper and bottle collection is near collapse. Two months ago we were warned that most Queensland councils would scrap recycling if government subsidies were not introduced. They said that rising transport and low commodity prices were to blame. One private operator in Canberra has informed residents that it will no longer recycle cardboard boxes, and this is at a time when Canberrans are being warned that their current disposal practices will exhaust landfill capacity within five years.

According to the ALGA, there is no way that national landfill reduction targets of 50 to 60 per cent are going to be met without quite large ratepayer subsidies. The $100 million per annum needed every year is a sum of money which is going to be required indefinitely. Local government is subsidising the cost of recycling by about $100 million a year, as I said, and this situation is demanding choices that should not have to be made. Does a council, for instance, maintain its recycling program at the expense of its child-care centre? Does another council sacrifice library facilities in order to continue recycling?

Local government is currently negotiating a voluntary agreement with state and federal governments and industry—the national packaging covenant. Local government and industry have agreed that we must start to find ways of funding this $100 million gap between the cost of providing recycling and the sale value of recycled materials. It is no longer seen as fair for ratepayers to bear this burden alone.

We know that many industries produce products with wasteful packaging that has no value once the product has been opened. I think the cult of the plastic bag particularly goes on in our society unquestioned. Although local government and households are crucial in the recycling loop, the current crisis will remain until federal and state governments and industry take much more initiative than we have seen thus far. State governments have been criticised for invariably taking the easy road—that is, they increase the burden on local governments rather than promote and demand that industry play that role.

The era of serious environmental commitment on the part of industry has not yet arrived. Whilst we might see dolphins and the liberal use of the words `green and clean' on supermarket products, they are no guarantee of sustainable practices. The cleaning product you may buy might have a triangle stamped on it indicating that it can be recycled, but the container often has not been made of recycled materials, and the symbol is there as a vague suggestion by the manufacturer that someone somewhere might may be able to recycle it. Greenpeace recently alerted us to the fact that less than one per cent of PVC produced in Australia is being recycled. It is present in many common items, such as food wrappers and soft drink bottles, and it is a major environmental hazard.

A local government task force has looked at a number of possibilities. They include: a raw material tax; a retail levy; container deposit legislation, such as that operating successfully over many years in South Australia; a waste disposal landfill levy; industry self-regulation, although this ends up being essentially the status quo; voluntary/legislated industry funds, a broadly based industry levy; a national equalisation fund, and these types of funds are common in the agricultural sector and are used to even out price fluctuations; advance disposal fees, a surcharge on products to pay for later disposal; commodity prices fixed within an agreed floor and ceiling; and supplementary rates and charges, or user pays.

The principle of product stewardship is essential to the success of any agreement between industry and the three tiers of government. Increasingly, we see it at work in Europe, but here, it seems, it needs a lot more work. This principle relates to the entire life cycle of a product: from the raw materials through to the design stage of the product, packaging, manufacturers and users—with everyone participating in the arrival of a new product and accepting the responsibility for its environmental impact.

Talks between Australian and New Zealand ministers last month also raised the prospect of `take back' provisions. These would require companies to recover, reuse and recycle a certain percentage of their packaging. The Financial Review noted that this would affect companies such as CCL, CUB and Kelloggs.

The ALGA has called for federal assistance in recycling totalling $25 million a year for the next four years. Like many sensible environmental measures, this is likely to receive a lukewarm response from the federal government. But reinstituting sales tax exemptions for products made from recycled material, such as paper, would go some way towards changing what is a desperate picture.

In talks late last month in Adelaide between industry and federal and state ministers, packaging companies baulked at that idea of paying the estimated $30 million, which represents their share of the cost of recycling, saying that it would eat into their profits. Whilst it is possible to be sympathetic to the arguments of local players that global operators are able to cut costs aggressively, the question must be asked: where does this leave local government? The answer is: it leaves local government bearing most of the financial burden.

I think now is the time for the federal government to do as local government suggests—that is, to back its policy stance and to assist in the development of a long-term econ omically sustainable recycling program in Australia. I suggest we cannot go back to putting all of our refuse into the rubbish bin. Fortunately, more than 70 per cent of Australians have already changed their habits—and I think that is a permanent change—and now is the time for federal government to act.

subdebate.1.para: The following document was tabled by the Clerk:
Telecommunications Act—Telecommunications (Customer Service Guarantee) Direction No. 1 of 1997 (Amendment No. 1 of 1998).

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the regional forest agreement (RFA) now being prepared for the Central Gippsland area in Victoria:

(1) Can a list and copies of all documents or other information provided by the Victorian Government to the forest taskforce in relation to land vested in the Victorian Plantations Corporation (VPC) be provided.

(2) Has the Victorian Government advised that land vested in the VPC only has plantations on it and no native forest; if not, can a list be provided of the parcels of land stated to have native forest.
(3) Is land vested in the VPC being investigated as part of the RFA for incorporation into the reserve system; if not, why not.

(4) What steps have been taken or will be taken to ensure that the Victorian Government does not pre-empt the RFA by issuing licences over VPC land for use as plantations in perpetuity, as provided for under legislation which has just passed through the Victorian Parliament.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Victorian Government has provided to the Forests Taskforce only one document which is a copy of a response from a Victorian minister to a submission from Victorian residents. Victoria's agreement has been obtained to the release of this document, a copy of which will be forwarded to the honourable senator separately by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and will be available to other senators through the Table Office.
(2) No. The Forests Taskforce has not sought a list of parcels of VPC land stated to have native forest.

(3) The Commonwealth and Victorian Governments will make a decision on this matter as we move towards the development of the Gippsland RFA. As a precaution Victoria has agreed that any harvesting of native forest vested in the VPC will only occur on the basis that values which may be required for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system are not compromised.
(4) Not applicable given answer to (3) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to Senator Conroy's question without notice (Hansard , 6 April 1998 p2055) concerning new anti-dividend streaming provisions and Senator Kemp's response (Hansard , 8 April 1998 p2356) that if some shareholders are more able to use franking benefits than other shareholders, the streaming provisions may apply, depending on the particular facts, notwithstanding that all shareholders are paid franked dividends; and with reference to the example given, that if one shareholder more able to use franking credits receives a large franked dividend, and another, less able to use franking credits, receives a small franked dividend and to compensate, other benefits, the proposed dividend streaming rule could apply:

(a) If it is assumed in the example given that the shareholder receives `a small franked dividend' and receives no other benefits by way of compensation or otherwise and it is also assumed that there is no scheme for the disposition shares for the purpose of conferring a tax advantage in relation to franking; will the new anti-dividend streaming provisions under Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1997 apply.

(b) Will these new anti-dividend streaming provisions ever apply to differential dividend amounts paid to different classes of shareholders who also received dividends franked to the same extent, where no shareholders receive other benefits to compensate and where there is no scheme for the disposition of shares for a purpose of conferring a tax advantage in relation to franking.
(c) Can examples be provided of how the new anti-dividend streaming provisions might apply in the circumstances described.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The new anti-dividend streaming rule (section 160AQCBA) included in Taxation Laws Amend ment Act (No. 3) 1998, (previously Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1997), will apply where a company is streaming the payment of dividends to its shareholders. Dividend streaming can occur where shareholders in a company do not receive franked dividends commensurate with their effective interest in the profits of the company. However, an essential element of dividend streaming is that shareholders are distinguished on the basis of their ability to use franking benefits.

(a) Section 160AQCBA would not apply in the circumstances outlined in question (a) providing that all shareholders receive franked dividends commensurate with their effective interest in the profits of the company. However, it would not always be necessary that all shareholders with the same effective interest in a company participate in the same dividend to the same extent. For example, 160AQCBA would not apply where shareholders with the same effective interest in a company participated in different dividends at different times but ultimately received the same amount of franked dividends.

(b) Similarly, section 160AQCBA would not apply in the circumstances described in question (b) providing all shareholders received franked dividends commensurate with their effective interest in the profits of the company.

(c) On the other hand, section 160AQCBA would apply if for example the company paid a fully-franked dividend of, say, $1,000 to one shareholder able to fully use franking credits, and a franked dividend of $1 to another shareholder with the same interest in the company but who is unable to use franking credits, where the differential dividend payment is part of a strategy to avoid wastage of franking credits.

subdebateinfo.title: Regional Forest Agreements in Tasmania and Victoria
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1203)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 29 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 1123 concerning regional forest agreements (RFAs) in Tasmania and Victoria, which states `The Government is well aware that no government, current or future, can bind the Parliament to appropriate monies whether for the payment of compensation or otherwise', this being the case:
(1) What provisions in the RFAs are legally binding.
(2) (a) Who is bound; and (b) to do what.
(3) What are the effects of any breach of these legal obligations.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Provisions in Part 3 of the Tasmanian and Central Highlands Regional Forest Agreements (RFAs) are intended by the Commonwealth and the relevant states, which are Parties to those RFAs, to create legally enforceable rights and obligations.
(2) (a) The Parties to each of the RFAs are bound, that is the Commonwealth and the relevant state.

(b) The Parties are bound to comply with the provisions in Part 3 of the RFAs. For the Tasmanian RFA, these provisions relate to forest management, compensation, priority species, review of sustainable high quality sawlog levels, review of pricing and allocation policies for commercial Government owned forestry operations, financial assistance and termination of the RFA. For the Central Highlands RFA, these provisions relate to forest management, compensation, industry development funding and termination of the RFA.
